head.title: A Berlin Transformer Plant Transformed Into a Museum

hedline.hl1: A Berlin Transformer Plant Transformed Into a Museum

abstract.p: Vitra Design Museum, Weil am Rhein, Germany, opens satellite in Berlin, housed in 1930's transformer plant; photos (Currents column) (S)

block.p: The Vitra Design Museum, in Weil am Rhein, Germany, has been a destination for design devotees since the late 1980's. Led by Alexander von Vegesack, the museum has staged some extensive modern design shows (including ''Charles and Ray Eames: A Legacy of Invention'' and ''Frank Lloyd Wright: The Living City''). Frustrated by a lack of sufficient space for its shows, the museum is now opening satellite branches. The first is in Berlin, where Mateo Kries, the curator, will oversee installations in a 300-foot 1930's transformer plant. The building's tower (above) houses a cool control room with original switches and fittings. A Verner Panton exhibition, to include the Panton chair (top, in the control room), will open the museum on July 1.
